awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Using Data Mining to Optimally Customize Therapy for Individuals with Autism
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will revolutionize the treatment of individuals with autism. One of every sixty-eight US children has autism (over 1.1 million). The estimated cost of providing Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) therapy to those who could benefit is $7.5 billion dollars annually. Societal impacts include: 1) more individuals with autism across the globe will receive treatment regimens that will enable them to live more fulfilled lives and reach their full potential; 2) families whose children are good candidates for treatment and receive it will experience reduced stress and better family life; and 3) the additional lifetime cost of not effectively treating children with autism, which is approximately ten-fold the cost of treatment, will be reduced. Because high-quality, contextually rich ABA performance data will be collected for the first time, efforts to apply data analytics will contribute in two important ways: a) patterns may be discerned across individuals with autism to better understand variations in autism and create therapies to target these differences; b) expansion of the frontiers of data mining to provide guidance in real time will contribute to a number of areas within and beyond ABA therapy.

The proposed project will optimize therapy outcomes for individuals with autism by transforming agent-based guiding technology into an adaptive and intelligent ABA therapy assistant for supervisors and instructors. The project pushes the boundaries in providing cost-effective, adaptable, intelligent, real-time guidance and data-collection support to instructors that integrates naturally into the instructional process and is easy to learn and use. ABA therapy experts, supervisors and instructors will verify the analyses and resulting guidance incorporated into the technology.  Advanced theories of usability engineering, including some developed by the project team, will be used to build interfaces that supervisors and instructors can intuit without the need for learning new concepts and syntax. The project will utilize the collected logs from multiple sessions with multiple therapy recipients and multiple therapy providers to uncover hidden patterns and assist supervisors in selecting appropriate therapy steps personalized for the individual with autism. The project will build on a large body of recent work in visualization, machine learning on temporal predictive modeling and sequential pattern mining, including some of the previous results of the project team. Special attention will be paid to the recent work in educational data mining and intelligent tutoring.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a developmental disability associated with significant social, communication, learning, and behavioral challenges. More than 3.5 million Americans are considered to have an ASD. Care for ASD will cost U.S. citizens $461 billion annually by 2025, exceeding yearly care costs for diabetes, ADHD, and stroke, but increasing availability of high-quality services could reduce these costs. High-quality, intensive Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) is the most effective and scientifically-validated approach to remediate impairments associated with ASD. Intensive, consistent, data-based ABA therapy improves communication, socialization, and adaptive outcomes for individuals with ASD. However, the per capita supply of qualified behavior practitioners is significantly below acceptable benchmark rates in 49 states and the District of Columbia. In rural and other marginalized areas, the dearth of service providers is even more pronounced, resulting in greater delays to treatment and limited service access.

This was an especially ambitious, high-risk, high-payoff project to build smart technology to guide instructors and caregivers to provide high quality ABA therapy to help individuals with ASD overcome developmental challenges and lead a better life. This project resulted in the release of GAINS (Guidance, Assessment, and Information System), the premier clinical support technology to improve ABA Therapy.  GAINS is a smart technology platform that uniquely incorporates knowledge of ABA theory and practice personalized for the individual with developmental challenges. GAINS is NOT a training app and NOT solely a data collection app, although increased knowledge and easier and better data collection with improved analysis are by-products of using GAINS. In a similar way to navigation systems for drivers, GAINS is a unique navigation system for instructors and caregivers implementing ABA therapy programs that help learners acquire skills and improve prosocial behaviors. Just like all drivers find useful the immediate updating of directions based on driver decisions and changes in the itinerary, all instructors and caregivers find useful the immediate updating of therapy program progress based on learner actions and updates to therapy programs. For instructors and caregivers who lack behavior expertise, in addition to providing what to do and when to do it, GAINS provides detailed step-by-step guidance on how to execute ABA therapy programs. GAINS enables the capture of high-quality, context-rich data that can be mined. To maximize the value and accessibility of data captured by GAINS to behavior supervisors in managing ABA therapy for an individual with ASD, preliminary versions of dashboards for supervisors that merge visual analytics with predictive modeling of trial data were built. Because student learning data are unique, these dashboards leverage “small data” for student-level personalization of ABA therapy. Some progress was made in exploring machine learning methods for short and long term prediction of student progress through therapy programs in a way that could be useful for real-time adjustment of student therapy.

Best practice guidelines call for ABA that includes at least 25 hours of therapy delivered with high fidelity and informed by ongoing data collection and analysis. However, most children receive less than 10 hours due to provider shortage and costs. When ABA therapy is accessible, consistency across behavior practitioners and caregivers is critical because lapses in treatment reduce its effectiveness. However, given caregivers’ limited training and high turnover of behavior technicians, implementing complex ABA treatment programs can be a challenge. Project results will accelerate adoption of unique, cost-effective smart technology that will improve program fidelity and bridge the gap in ABA instruction that individuals with ASD experience. This will especially help marginalized communities who continue to suffer more because of inadequate access to quality ABA therapy. For those with ASD, accelerated adoption of GAINS smart technology will improve life skills and social interaction, which has the potential to promote greater attainment of schooling, inclusion, independent living, and vocational outcomes.


Last Modified: 10/29/2021
Modified by: John T Nosek
